author: Staff Reporter
text:
Shashi Tharoor, MP, speaking at the Philip C. Jessup International Law Moot Court Competition in Bengaluru on Sunday.— photo: by special arrangement

Should citizens’ privacy be compromised for the sake of national security? This was the question law school teams battled over at the Philip C. Jessup International Law Moot Court Competition national finals held at Christ College here on Sunday. In the end, the team from Gujarat National Law University (GNLU), Ahmedabad, was adjudged the winner.

Anand Deshpande, Sharngan Aravindakshan, Rohan George, Amrita Mohan and Chethana Venkataraghavan were part of the winning team.

The GNLU team argued against the team from the National Academy of Legal Studies and Research (NALSAR), Hyderabad. The top four teams at the event will go on to participate in the international finals at Washington D.C.

Shashi Tharoor, MP, who was the chief guest at the valedictory session, praised the students for their eloquent arguments. “Whether you have won or not, you have applied your minds to issues of international importance, which is commendable,” he said.

The moot court explored, through a fictional dispute, the legality of cyber surveillance and cyber attacks in the face of threats to national security. The speakers for the applicant team from NALSAR, Chinmayee Sharma and Dibankar Ghosh, argued that cyber surveillance was “unjustified and discriminatory,” while the respondents argued that espionage was admissible if it could save lives.
title: GNLU wins national finals of Jessup moot court competition
